quote good version out of this?

Well as it turns out, overnight
salads are actually a thing,

the idea being that the different
ingredients are layered,
and then covered with a thick dressing,
preventing the vegetables from wilting,
and anything from getting too soggy.
So as you might be able to tell,

I'm starting this out
by making my own mayo.

Combining a whole egg,
teaspoon of mustard,
a pinch of salt, and a scoche of lemon
in an immersion blender jar.
Then slowly pouring one cup

of neutral-flavored oil
like canola over top,

and blending until a thick
flavorful emulsion forms,
otherwise known as mayonnaise.

This is gonna act as the basis
for our Russian dressing,

because we're gonna
make an overnight salad
inspired by a Reuben sandwich.
So into a bowl goes our mayo,
a third of a cup of chili sauce,
three tablespoons of prepared horseradish,

one teaspoon of the hot
sauce of your choice,
one teaspoon Worcestershire sauce,
one teaspoon sweet paprika,

and a couple tablespoons
of finely minced onion.

Go ahead and tiny whisk those
to a state of homogeneity,

cover and refrigerate
for at least an hour,
we want this to firm up a bit
before we top our salad with it.

In place of cookie croutons,
we're gonna make croutons,
and since this is a Reuben salad,
we're going to use rye bread.

Simply cube up a bunch
of your favorite rye,
drizzle it generously with olive oil,

sprinkle with kosher salt
and freshly ground pepper,
toss around, spread out,
and bake in a 300 degree Fahrenheit oven,
for anywhere from 20 to 40 minutes,

until they're lightly
golden brown and dry,
then it's time to address our meat.
Standing in for our hot dogs,
is a big old chunk of deli pastrami,

which at first we're
gonna slice into cubes,
but then we're gonna realize
that those aren't quite tender enough,
so we're gonna slice them down
into nice thin little pastrami bits.
Last bit of prep is to shred up
a whole bunch of Swiss cheese,

and with that we're
finally ready to assemble.

the arugula is going to

Speaking of which here comes some Swiss,

chopped cornichon pickles,
optional, but they're gonna bring

generous but not overwhelming

then I'm going to layer in
some more arugula, cabbage,

hopefully help insulate

our rye croutons from
the moisture of the meat.
Let's get those on in there,

and then one last layer
of green and purple stuff.

trying to lightly compress

through which the

making sure not to rush
in Russian dressing.
Covering with plastic wrap,
